name: planner
content:
Plan:
   - Step 1:
         * sub-task: Analyze the course idea and define core competencies
         * agent: researcher
         * bullet points:
           - Extract the target audience (cross-functional professionals) and duration (24 hours) from the brief.
           - Identify core competencies aligned to the idea: prompt/context fundamentals; context engineering with Custom Instructions/Memory; web-grounded research with Browse; ADA multi-file analysis; Vision for documents/tables; image generation; building Custom GPTs with Knowledge and structured outputs; governance/workspace controls; end-to-end workflow integration.
           - Translate competencies into observable skills and behaviors (what participants should be able to do by end of course).
           - Note constraints and emphases from the brief: stronger focus on context/memory, deep Vision and Custom GPT labs, decision-tree fallbacks for feature availability, synthetic data/redaction SOP, artifact-based quick checks.
   - Step 2:
         * sub-task: Determine prerequisites and readiness
         * agent: researcher
         * bullet points:
           - Define knowledge prerequisites (basic digital literacy; comfort with CSV/PDF/PNG; no-code mindset; basic data and research literacy).
           - Define account/feature prerequisites (ChatGPT Plus/Teams with ADA, Browse, Vision, Image Gen, Custom GPT Builder; or instructor-provided tenant) and hardware/browser requirements.
           - List pre-course setup tasks: verify feature availability; confirm file upload permissions; download synthetic dataset/knowledge pack; confirm privacy awareness (no PHI/confidential data).
           - Specify time expectations (24 contact hours + 2 hours optional practice).
   - Step 3:
         * sub-task: Propose module sequence and timeboxing
         * agent: researcher
         * bullet points:
           - Propose 8 main modules (3 hours each) that progress from fundamentals to advanced application, matching the provided module themes.
           - Map each module to specific tools/features: Prompting/CI; Browse; ADA; Vision; Image Gen; Custom GPT Builder + Knowledge + no-code Actions pattern; Teams/Enterprise; Capstone.
           - Place assessment touchpoints after Modules 2, 4, 5, and 7; include a final capstone in Module 8.
           - Allocate hands-on exercise time within each module (estimate per module), ensuring cumulative time fits 24 hours.
   - Step 4:
         * sub-task: Draft module-level descriptions, learning goals, and takeaways
         * agent: researcher
         * bullet points:
           - For each module, write: a concise description of what the session covers; explicit tools/features taught; key takeaways; and 4–6 specific learning goals phrased as “Participants [action verb]…”.
           - Include exercise duration estimates for hands-on components per module.
           - Incorporate mention of decision-tree/fallbacks where feature availability may vary (e.g., ADA alternatives, simulating Custom GPTs with files).
           - Keep scope to structure, goals, and takeaways—do not include slides, scripts, or full exercise materials.
   - Step 5:
         * sub-task: Quality assurance and alignment check
         * agent: researcher
         * bullet points:
           - Verify that modules reflect the deeper Vision and Custom GPT labs, and that context/memory emphasis is evident.
           - Ensure every module explicitly names the tools/features covered and that tool coverage matches the idea (ADA, Browse, Vision, Image Gen, File uploads, Memory/CI, Custom GPT Builder/Knowledge/GPT Store, Teams/Enterprise).
           - Confirm assessment touchpoints are called out (without rubrics) and that artifact-based quick checks are referenced at appropriate modules.
           - Check time totals and exercise estimates align to 24 hours; ensure prerequisites are clearly stated; maintain a senior-researcher tone.
   - Step 6:
         * sub-task: Produce the full Course Outline in structured markdown
         * agent: researcher
         * bullet points:
           - Include course title, duration, audience, prerequisites/readiness.
           - List 8 modules with: module title, duration, description (with explicit tools/features), key takeaways, learning goals (“Participants [action verb]…”), and hands-on exercise duration.
           - Briefly note assessment touchpoints (Modules 2, 4, 5, 7) and capstone expectations in Module 8.
           - Keep the outline focused on course structure, learning goals, and takeaways only.

name: planner_response_formatter
content:
**PLAN**

- Step 1:
	* sub-task: Analyze the course idea and define core competencies
	* agent in charge: researcher

	* instructions:
		- Extract the target audience (cross-functional professionals) and duration (24 hours) from the brief.
		- Identify core competencies aligned to the idea: prompt/context fundamentals; context engineering with Custom Instructions/Memory; web-grounded research with Browse; ADA multi-file analysis; Vision for documents/tables; image generation; building Custom GPTs with Knowledge and structured outputs; governance/workspace controls; end-to-end workflow integration.
		- Translate competencies into observable skills and behaviors (what participants should be able to do by end of course).
		- Note constraints and emphases from the brief: stronger focus on context/memory, deep Vision and Custom GPT labs, decision-tree fallbacks for feature availability, synthetic data/redaction SOP, artifact-based quick checks.

- Step 2:
	* sub-task: Determine prerequisites and readiness
	* agent in charge: researcher

	* instructions:
		- Define knowledge prerequisites (basic digital literacy; comfort with CSV/PDF/PNG; no-code mindset; basic data and research literacy).
		- Define account/feature prerequisites (ChatGPT Plus/Teams with ADA, Browse, Vision, Image Gen, Custom GPT Builder; or instructor-provided tenant) and hardware/browser requirements.
		- List pre-course setup tasks: verify feature availability; confirm file upload permissions; download synthetic dataset/knowledge pack; confirm privacy awareness (no PHI/confidential data).
		- Specify time expectations (24 contact hours + 2 hours optional practice).

- Step 3:
	* sub-task: Propose module sequence and timeboxing
	* agent in charge: researcher

	* instructions:
		- Propose 8 main modules (3 hours each) that progress from fundamentals to advanced application, matching the provided module themes.
		- Map each module to specific tools/features: Prompting/CI; Browse; ADA; Vision; Image Gen; Custom GPT Builder + Knowledge + no-code Actions pattern; Teams/Enterprise; Capstone.
		- Place assessment touchpoints after Modules 2, 4, 5, and 7; include a final capstone in Module 8.
		- Allocate hands-on exercise time within each module (estimate per module), ensuring cumulative time fits 24 hours.

- Step 4:
	* sub-task: Draft module-level descriptions, learning goals, and takeaways
	* agent in charge: researcher

	* instructions:
		- For each module, write: a concise description of what the session covers; explicit tools/features taught; key takeaways; and 4–6 specific learning goals phrased as “Participants [action verb]…”.
		- Include exercise duration estimates for hands-on components per module.
		- Incorporate mention of decision-tree/fallbacks where feature availability may vary (e.g., ADA alternatives, simulating Custom GPTs with files).
		- Keep scope to structure, goals, and takeaways—do not include slides, scripts, or full exercise materials.

- Step 5:
	* sub-task: Quality assurance and alignment check
	* agent in charge: researcher

	* instructions:
		- Verify that modules reflect the deeper Vision and Custom GPT labs, and that context/memory emphasis is evident.
		- Ensure every module explicitly names the tools/features covered and that tool coverage matches the idea (ADA, Browse, Vision, Image Gen, File uploads, Memory/CI, Custom GPT Builder/Knowledge/GPT Store, Teams/Enterprise).
		- Confirm assessment touchpoints are called out (without rubrics) and that artifact-based quick checks are referenced at appropriate modules.
		- Check time totals and exercise estimates align to 24 hours; ensure prerequisites are clearly stated; maintain a senior-researcher tone.

- Step 6:
	* sub-task: Produce the full Course Outline in structured markdown
	* agent in charge: researcher

	* instructions:
		- Include course title, duration, audience, prerequisites/readiness.
		- List 8 modules with: module title, duration, description (with explicit tools/features), key takeaways, learning goals (“Participants [action verb]…”), and hands-on exercise duration.
		- Briefly note assessment touchpoints (Modules 2, 4, 5, 7) and capstone expectations in Module 8.
		- Keep the outline focused on course structure, learning goals, and takeaways only.

name: plan_reviewer
content:
Recommendations:

- Step 1 — sharpen expected outputs and acceptance criteria
  - Modification: Add explicit, tangible outputs the researcher must produce from the analysis (so later steps can reference them).
  - Bullet instructions for the researcher:
    - Produce a "Core Competencies Matrix" (spreadsheet) that lists each competency, associated observable behaviors, one or two example assessment artifacts, and mapped modules (one row per competency).
    - For each competency, assign a difficulty level (Foundational / Intermediate / Advanced) and an estimated teaching time (minutes).
    - Produce a short paragraph (2–3 sentences) summarizing constraints and emphases (context/memory, Vision, Custom GPTs, fallbacks) and list 3 risk areas (feature unavailability, privacy/PHI, tenant permissions).
    - Deliverable: core_competencies_matrix.xlsx and constraints_summary.md.
    - Acceptance check: ensure every competency maps to at least one module and an artifact type.

- Step 2 — make prerequisites actionable and testable
  - Modification: Convert prerequisites into an exact pre-course checklist and automated verification steps instructors/learners can follow.
  - Bullet instructions for the researcher:
    - Create a "Pre-course Readiness Checklist" with binary checks (Yes/No) for accounts, specific feature flags (ADA, Browse, Vision, Image gen, Builder), and browser/upload permissions.
    - Add fallback instructions per missing feature (e.g., if ADA missing: instruct on simulated ADA workflow with spreadsheet + spec; if Builder missing: simulate with base ChatGPT plus files).
    - Specify required sample files and provide exact file names and minimal content templates (e.g., sales_q1_q4.csv template header + one row).
    - Deliverable: pre_course_checklist.pdf and fallback_instructions.md.
    - Acceptance check: checklist must be runnable by an instructor in ≤30 minutes.

- Step 3 — tighten module sequencing and explicit time allocation per segment
  - Modification: Break each 3-hour module into lecture/demo / hands-on / review / buffer segments so total time and pacing are explicit.
  - Bullet instructions for the researcher:
    - For each module, produce a time split (e.g., 45m lecture/demo, 90m hands-on lab, 20m artifact review/peer QA, 25m buffer/Q&A) that sums to 180 minutes; note where breaks should occur across the whole day.
    - Map each module to the specific artifacts learners will produce and to the assessment touchpoints (link to Step 1 matrix).
    - Identify modules where alternate flow is needed if feature unavailable (point to Step 2 fallbacks) and indicate exact conditional path (e.g., "If Builder disabled → follow simulation path A").
    - Deliverable: module_timing_plan.csv (module, segment, minutes).
    - Acceptance check: cumulative minutes across modules = 24 hours; include total buffer time ≥30 minutes.

- Step 4 — make module learning goals SMART and attach artifact templates
  - Modification: Require each learning goal to be SMART (Specific, Measurable, Achievable, Relevant, Time-bound) and link each module to a minimal artifact template name and expected format.
  - Bullet instructions for the researcher:
    - For each module, rewrite the 4–6 learning goals to be SMART; e.g., "Participants produce a 150-word ADA summary that correctly calculates variance and is exportable as summary.txt."
    - For each module, list the exact artifact filename(s) learners should produce (e.g., kpi_table.csv, coverage_limits.csv, ci_template.txt) and one-line acceptance criteria for that artifact.
    - Provide an estimated hands-on exercise time (minutes) per module and a short instructor cue list (3 bullets) on what the instructor should observe during lab.
    - Deliverable: modules_learning_goals_and_artifacts.md and artifact_acceptance_criteria.csv.
    - Acceptance check: every module has at least one measurable artifact and one acceptance criterion.

- Step 5 — strengthen QA with concrete checks, pass/fail rules, and accessibility
  - Modification: Expand QA step to produce a QA checklist, explicit pass/fail thresholds for checkpoint artifacts, and an accessibility/inclusion checklist.
  - Bullet instructions for the researcher:
    - Create a "QA & Assessment Checklist" that enumerates the checkpoint artifacts (Modules 2, 4, 5, 7), and for each give the rubric thresholds (e.g., average ≥3.0, no criterion <2) and the remediation path for failing learners.
    - Add an accessibility inspection list for artifacts and outputs (alt-text, color contrast checks for images, plain-language requirements) and require at least one accessibility test per relevant module.
    - Produce a "Feature-failure test plan" that lists 3 realistic failure scenarios (e.g., Vision OCR fails on skewed image, ADA resource not available) and the instructor's fallback script for each.
    - Deliverable: qa_checklist.xlsx, accessibility_checks.md, failure_test_plan.md.
    - Acceptance check: QA list includes remediation steps and timeline (≤1 week) for reassessment.

- Step 6 — standardize the final markdown outline and include crosswalks
  - Modification: Require final Course Outline markdown to include a crosswalk to the original syllabus fields and a short instructor facilitation guide (not lesson content).
  - Bullet instructions for the researcher:
    - Produce the Course Outline in structured markdown that includes: title, duration, audience, prerequisites, module table (title, duration, tools/features, key takeaways, SMART learning goals, hands-on minutes), and explicit artifact filenames.
    - Add a "Syllabus CSV crosswalk" section mapping each module row to the original idea01_syllabus.csv fields (so downstream content creators can reconcile).
    - Append a 1-page "Instructor Facilitation Notes" per module with 5 quick cues (start phrase, demo checklist, common learner pitfall, fallback step, assessment cue).
    - Deliverable: course_outline.md and syllabus_crosswalk.csv and facilitation_notes.pdf.
    - Acceptance check: markdown file validated against the required fields; crosswalk covers all 8 modules and assessment touchpoints.

Notes on distribution of subtasks and capabilities
- Keep the plan's single-agent model: researcher performs all sub-tasks. Each step remains one sub-task assigned to researcher — no other agents are introduced.
- Each step now produces concrete, named deliverables which later steps reference; this ensures clear handoffs and traceability.
- The added acceptance checks let the researcher know when a step is complete and ready for the next step without additional agents.

name: reviewer_response_formatter
content:
**Recommendations:**

Step 1 — sharpen expected outputs and acceptance criteria
- Modification: Add explicit, tangible outputs the researcher must produce from the analysis (so later steps can reference them).
- Researcher instructions:
  - Produce a 'Core Competencies Matrix' (spreadsheet) that lists each competency, associated observable behaviors, one or two example assessment artifacts, and mapped modules (one row per competency).
  - For each competency, assign a difficulty level (Foundational / Intermediate / Advanced) and an estimated teaching time (minutes).
  - Produce a short paragraph (2–3 sentences) summarizing constraints and emphases (context/memory, Vision, Custom GPTs, fallbacks) and list 3 risk areas (feature unavailability, privacy/PHI, tenant permissions).
- Deliverable: core_competencies_matrix.xlsx and constraints_summary.md.
- Acceptance check: ensure every competency maps to at least one module and an artifact type.

Step 2 — make prerequisites actionable and testable
- Modification: Convert prerequisites into an exact pre-course checklist and automated verification steps instructors/learners can follow.
- Researcher instructions:
  - Create a 'Pre-course Readiness Checklist' with binary checks (Yes/No) for accounts, specific feature flags (ADA, Browse, Vision, Image gen, Builder), and browser/upload permissions.
  - Add fallback instructions per missing feature (e.g., if ADA missing: instruct on simulated ADA workflow with spreadsheet + spec; if Builder missing: simulate with base ChatGPT plus files).
  - Specify required sample files and provide exact file names and minimal content templates (e.g., sales_q1_q4.csv template header + one row).
- Deliverable: pre_course_checklist.pdf and fallback_instructions.md.
- Acceptance check: checklist must be runnable by an instructor in ≤30 minutes.

Step 3 — tighten module sequencing and explicit time allocation per segment
- Modification: Break each 3-hour module into lecture/demo / hands-on / review / buffer segments so total time and pacing are explicit.
- Researcher instructions:
  - For each module, produce a time split (e.g., 45m lecture/demo, 90m hands-on lab, 20m artifact review/peer QA, 25m buffer/Q&A) that sums to 180 minutes; note where breaks should occur across the whole day.
  - Map each module to the specific artifacts learners will produce and to the assessment touchpoints (link to Step 1 matrix).
  - Identify modules where alternate flow is needed if feature unavailable (point to Step 2 fallbacks) and indicate exact conditional path (e.g., 'If Builder disabled → follow simulation path A').
- Deliverable: module_timing_plan.csv (module, segment, minutes).
- Acceptance check: cumulative minutes across modules = 24 hours; include total buffer time ≥30 minutes.

Step 4 — make module learning goals SMART and attach artifact templates
- Modification: Require each learning goal to be SMART (Specific, Measurable, Achievable, Relevant, Time-bound) and link each module to a minimal artifact template name and expected format.
- Researcher instructions:
  - For each module, rewrite the 4–6 learning goals to be SMART; e.g., 'Participants produce a 150-word ADA summary that correctly calculates variance and is exportable as summary.txt.'
  - For each module, list the exact artifact filename(s) learners should produce (e.g., kpi_table.csv, coverage_limits.csv, ci_template.txt) and one-line acceptance criteria for that artifact.
  - Provide an estimated hands-on exercise time (minutes) per module and a short instructor cue list (3 bullets) on what the instructor should observe during lab.
- Deliverable: modules_learning_goals_and_artifacts.md and artifact_acceptance_criteria.csv.
- Acceptance check: every module has at least one measurable artifact and one acceptance criterion.

Step 5 — strengthen QA with concrete checks, pass/fail rules, and accessibility
- Modification: Expand QA step to produce a QA checklist, explicit pass/fail thresholds for checkpoint artifacts, and an accessibility/inclusion checklist.
- Researcher instructions:
  - Create a 'QA & Assessment Checklist' that enumerates the checkpoint artifacts (Modules 2, 4, 5, 7), and for each give the rubric thresholds (e.g., average ≥3.0, no criterion <2) and the remediation path for failing learners.
  - Add an accessibility inspection list for artifacts and outputs (alt-text, color contrast checks for images, plain-language requirements) and require at least one accessibility test per relevant module.
  - Produce a 'Feature-failure test plan' that lists 3 realistic failure scenarios (e.g., Vision OCR fails on skewed image, ADA resource not available) and the instructor's fallback script for each.
- Deliverable: qa_checklist.xlsx, accessibility_checks.md, failure_test_plan.md.
- Acceptance check: QA list includes remediation steps and timeline (≤1 week) for reassessment.

Step 6 — standardize the final markdown outline and include crosswalks
- Modification: Require final Course Outline markdown to include a crosswalk to the original syllabus fields and a short instructor facilitation guide (not lesson content).
- Researcher instructions:
  - Produce the Course Outline in structured markdown that includes: title, duration, audience, prerequisites, module table (title, duration, tools/features, key takeaways, SMART learning goals, hands-on minutes), and explicit artifact filenames.
  - Add a 'Syllabus CSV crosswalk' section mapping each module row to the original idea01_syllabus.csv fields (so downstream content creators can reconcile).
  - Append a 1-page 'Instructor Facilitation Notes' per module with 5 quick cues (start phrase, demo checklist, common learner pitfall, fallback step, assessment cue).
- Deliverable: course_outline.md and syllabus_crosswalk.csv and facilitation_notes.pdf.
- Acceptance check: markdown file validated against the required fields; crosswalk covers all 8 modules and assessment touchpoints.

Notes on distribution of subtasks and capabilities
- Keep the plan's single-agent model: researcher performs all sub-tasks. Each step remains one sub-task assigned to researcher — no other agents are introduced.
- Each step now produces concrete, named deliverables which later steps reference; this ensures clear handoffs and traceability.
- The added acceptance checks let the researcher know when a step is complete and ready for the next step without additional agents.

name: _Group_Tool_Executor
content:
Recommendations have been logged.  
Number of feedback rounds left: 0. 
Now, update the plan accordingly, planner!

name: planner
content:
Plan:
   - Step 1:
         * sub-task: Analyze the course idea and define core competencies with outputs and risks
         * agent: researcher
         * bullet points:
           - Extract audience and duration, then enumerate competencies aligned to the idea (prompting/context, Custom Instructions/Memory, Browse, ADA, Vision, Image Gen, Custom GPT Builder + Knowledge + no-code Actions pattern, Teams/Enterprise governance, end-to-end integration).
           - Translate each competency into observable behaviors and example assessment artifacts; map each to relevant module(s).
           - Assign difficulty (Foundational/Intermediate/Advanced) and estimated teaching time (minutes) to each competency.
           - Summarize constraints/emphases (context/memory depth, Vision and Custom GPT labs, feature-availability decision tree/fallbacks, synthetic datasets/redaction SOP, artifact-based quick checks) and list 3 risk areas (feature unavailability, privacy/PHI, tenant permissions).
           - Deliverables: core_competencies_matrix.xlsx; constraints_summary.md.
           - Acceptance check: every competency maps to at least one module and at least one artifact type; total estimated minutes are plausible against 24 hours.

   - Step 2:
         * sub-task: Make prerequisites actionable and testable with fallbacks
         * agent: researcher
         * bullet points:
           - Create a Pre-course Readiness Checklist with binary Yes/No checks covering accounts, specific feature flags (ADA, Browse, Vision, Image Gen, Custom GPT Builder), browser and file-upload permissions, and hardware/browser norms.
           - Add stepwise fallback instructions per missing feature (e.g., ADA → spreadsheet + visual spec; Builder → simulate with base ChatGPT + files; Vision OCR issues → crop/re-upload + manual QA).
           - Specify required sample files with exact filenames and minimal content templates drawn from the idea (e.g., sales_q1_q4.csv, targets.csv, glossary.csv, Product_FAQ.docx, Policy_Guide.pdf, Brand_Guide.pdf) including headers and one illustrative row/page.
           - Deliverables: pre_course_checklist.pdf; fallback_instructions.md.
           - Acceptance check: an instructor can run the checklist end-to-end in ≤30 minutes; each missing feature has a clear fallback path.

   - Step 3:
         * sub-task: Tighten module sequencing, pacing, and alternates; produce timing plan
         * agent: researcher
         * bullet points:
           - Propose the 8-module sequence (3 hours each) matching the syllabus themes and tool coverage; place assessment touchpoints after Modules 2, 4, 5, 7; capstone in Module 8.
           - For each module, break 180 minutes into segments (lecture/demo, hands-on lab, artifact review/peer QA, buffer/Q&A) and indicate short breaks across the day.
           - Map module artifacts to be produced (use the explicit filenames from the idea) and link to competencies from Step 1.
           - Identify conditional paths per module if a feature is unavailable and reference Step 2 fallbacks (e.g., “If Builder disabled → follow simulation path A”).
           - Deliverable: module_timing_plan.csv (module, segment, minutes).
           - Acceptance check: cumulative minutes across all modules = 24:00; total buffer time across course ≥30 minutes; each module lists artifacts and alternates where needed.

   - Step 4:
         * sub-task: Make learning goals SMART and attach artifact templates and cues
         * agent: researcher
         * bullet points:
           - Rewrite 4–6 learning goals per module as SMART, explicitly tying to measurable artifacts (e.g., “Participants produce a 150-word ADA summary with correct variance as summary.txt”).
           - List exact artifact filename(s) per module and one-line acceptance criteria for each artifact; include expected format.
           - Provide estimated hands-on minutes per module and 3 instructor lab cues (what to observe, common struggle, success indicator).
           - Deliverables: modules_learning_goals_and_artifacts.md; artifact_acceptance_criteria.csv.
           - Acceptance check: every module has at least one measurable artifact and one acceptance criterion; hands-on minutes align with Step 3 timing.

   - Step 5:
         * sub-task: Strengthen QA with pass/fail rules, accessibility, and feature-failure tests
         * agent: researcher
         * bullet points:
           - Create a QA & Assessment Checklist enumerating checkpoint artifacts (Modules 2, 4, 5, 7) with rubric thresholds (avg ≥3.0, no criterion <2) and remediation paths/timelines (≤1 week) for reassessment.
           - Add an accessibility checklist (alt-text, color contrast checks for images, plain language, captioning if any media) and require at least one accessibility test per relevant module.
           - Produce a Feature-failure test plan with 3 realistic failure scenarios (e.g., Vision OCR fails on skewed image, ADA not available, Browse blocked), each with an instructor fallback script.
           - Deliverables: qa_checklist.xlsx; accessibility_checks.md; failure_test_plan.md.
           - Acceptance check: QA checklist includes thresholds, remediation steps, and timeline; accessibility list is applicable to modules with images/docs; at least 3 failure scenarios have actionable scripts.

   - Step 6:
         * sub-task: Produce the full Course Outline in structured markdown with crosswalks and facilitation notes
         * agent: researcher
         * bullet points:
           - Write the Course Outline in structured markdown including: title, duration, audience, prerequisites/readiness; modules table (title, duration, tools/features, description, key takeaways, SMART learning goals, hands-on minutes); explicit artifact filenames; assessment touchpoints; capstone expectations.
           - Add a Syllabus CSV crosswalk mapping each module to original idea01_syllabus.csv fields and artifacts for reconciliation by content creators.
           - Append 1-page Instructor Facilitation Notes per module with 5 cues: start phrase, demo checklist, common pitfall, fallback step, assessment cue.
           - Deliverables: course_outline.md; syllabus_crosswalk.csv; facilitation_notes.pdf.
           - Acceptance check: markdown includes all required fields; crosswalk covers all 8 modules and assessment touchpoints; notes reflect alternates and artifacts; tone matches senior-researcher guidance.

- Step 1:
	* sub-task: Analyze the course idea and define core competencies with outputs and risks
	* agent in charge: researcher

	* instructions:
		- Extract audience and duration, then enumerate competencies aligned to the idea (prompting/context, Custom Instructions/Memory, Browse, ADA, Vision, Image Gen, Custom GPT Builder + Knowledge + no-code Actions pattern, Teams/Enterprise governance, end-to-end integration).

- Step 3:
	* sub-task: Tighten module sequencing, pacing, and alternates; produce timing plan
	* agent in charge: researcher

	* instructions:
		- Propose the 8-module sequence (3 hours each) matching the syllabus themes and tool coverage; place assessment touchpoints after Modules 2, 4, 5, 7; capstone in Module 8.
		- For each module, break 180 minutes into segments (lecture/demo, hands-on lab, artifact review/peer QA, buffer/Q&A) and indicate short breaks across the day.

- Step 4:

		- List exact artifact filename(s) per module and one-line acceptance criteria for each artifact; include expected format.
		- Provide estimated hands-on minutes per module and 3 instructor lab cues (what to observe, common struggle, success indicator).
		- Deliverables: modules_learning_goals_and_artifacts.md; artifact_acceptance_criteria.csv.
		- Acceptance check: every module has at least one measurable artifact and one acceptance criterion; hands-on minutes align with Step 3 timing.

- Step 5:
	* sub-task: Strengthen QA with pass/fail rules, accessibility, and feature-failure tests
	* agent in charge: researcher

	* instructions:
		- Create a QA & Assessment Checklist enumerating checkpoint artifacts (Modules 2, 4, 5, 7) with rubric thresholds (avg ≥3.0, no criterion <2) and remediation paths/timelines (≤1 week) for reassessment.
		- Add an accessibility checklist (alt-text, color contrast checks for images, plain language, captioning if any media) and require at least one accessibility test per relevant module.
		- Produce a Feature-failure test plan with 3 realistic failure scenarios (e.g., Vision OCR fails on skewed image, ADA not available, Browse blocked), each with an instructor fallback script.
		- Deliverables: qa_checklist.xlsx; accessibility_checks.md; failure_test_plan.md.
		- Acceptance check: QA checklist includes thresholds, remediation steps, and timeline; accessibility list is applicable to modules with images/docs; at least 3 failure scenarios have actionable scripts.

- Step 6:
	* sub-task: Produce the full Course Outline in structured markdown with crosswalks and facilitation notes
	* agent in charge: researcher

	* instructions:
		- Write the Course Outline in structured markdown including: title, duration, audience, prerequisites/readiness; modules table (title, duration, tools/features, description, key takeaways, SMART learning goals, hands-on minutes); explicit artifact filenames; assessment touchpoints; capstone expectations.
		- Add a Syllabus CSV crosswalk mapping each module to original idea01_syllabus.csv fields and artifacts for reconciliation by content creators.
		- Append 1-page Instructor Facilitation Notes per module with 5 cues: start phrase, demo checklist, common pitfall, fallback step, assessment cue.
		- Deliverables: course_outline.md; syllabus_crosswalk.csv; facilitation_notes.pdf.
		- Acceptance check: markdown includes all required fields; crosswalk covers all 8 modules and assessment touchpoints; notes reflect alternates and artifacts; tone matches senior-researcher guidance.
